title: Apple unveils its first carbon neutral products - Apple
summary: Apple has unveiled its first-ever carbon neutral products in the all-new Apple Watch lineup. The company made significant progress towards its ambitious Apple 2030 climate goal by ending the use of leather across all of its product lines, using 30 percent recycled or renewable material by weight in the new products, and shipping 50 percent of products without the use of air transportation. Innovations in design, materials, and clean energy have driven dramatic reductions in product emissions of over 75 percent for each carbon neutral Apple Watch.
green_innovation: TRUE, the new Apple Watch lineup meets the criteria to be a green innovation because it contributes to environmental sustainability goals, such as decarbonisation, reducing or replacing harmful substances, and reducing resource consumption by developing a circular economy.
business_innovation: TRUE, the new Apple Watch lineup meets the criteria to be a business innovation because it is a new or significantly improved product that differs from the firm's previous products and has been introduced on the market.
green_product: TRUE,  the Apple Watch lineup meets the criteria to be a green product because it is designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: FALSE, the article does not describe a process that meets the criteria to be a green process.

title: How does technology affect the environment? - Telefónica
summary: Technology can have both positive and negative effects on the environment. On the one hand, it can be used to develop green innovations that help to reduce environmental impacts. On the other hand, the production and use of technology can also lead to pollution and other environmental problems.  The relationship between environment and technology is complex. However, with the right approach, technology can be a powerful tool for building a greener and more sustainable future.  Recent advances in technology have led to the development of new products and processes that help reduce environmental impacts.

title: European Commission Adopts Measures Restricting Intentional Microplastics - Cosmetics & Toiletries
summary: The European Commission has adopted measures to restrict microplastics in products under the EU chemical legislation REACH. The measures will prohibit the sale of microplastics, products to which microplastics have been intentionally added, and products that release those microplastics when used. The first measures, such as the ban on loose glitter and microbeads, will apply once the restriction enters into force — 20 days after the Sept. 25, 2023 announcement.
green_innovation: TRUE. The measures will prevent the release to the environment of approximately half a million tonnes of microplastics.

title: Vivobarefoot Is Serious About Circularity and Scoring Its Environmental Impact - Footwear News
summary: Vivobarefoot, a sustainable footwear brand, and Circ, a textile-to-textile recycling company, are partnering to develop footwear uppers made entirely of a single material (polyester) that can be chemically recycled and reused in the production of new footwear without the need to add any virgin materials. The goal is to create a shoe that is truly “recyclable.” The new footwear is slated to launch in fall 2024.

title: Turning waste textiles into new products in Hull - Innovation in Textiles
summary: MYGroup, a Yorkshire waste management firm, is investing £500,000 to build a sustainable textiles factory in Hull. The factory will house a complete, state-of-the-art recycling and remanufacturing process for waste textiles, from clothing to accessories and home furnishings. The new factory is set to be fully operational by the spring of 2024 and will create up to 30 jobs.

title: SLM Partners Launch New Ag Fund - WealthBriefingAsia
summary: SLM Partners and Impact Ag Partners have created a joint venture fund to invest in regenerative agriculture and carbon storage in Australia. This partnership, SLM Agri Carbon Fund, combines the experience of both companies in regenerative farming principles and carbon project development to scale up regenerative and low-carbon farming systems in Australia. The fund will acquire mixed farms in select regions of eastern Australia and implement regenerative practices such as large-scale rotational grazing, reduced tillage, cover cropping, integrating livestock with grain rotations, afforestation and environmental plantings of native vegetation.

business_innovation: TRUE, the fund represents a new business model for investing in regenerative agriculture and carbon storage in Australia.
green_product: FALSE, the article does not describe a specific green product.
green_process: TRUE, the fund will implement regenerative agriculture practices such as large-scale rotational grazing, reduced tillage, cover cropping, integrating livestock with grain rotations, afforestation and environmental plantings of native vegetation.

title: Apple to stop using leather in all new products - The Independent
summary: Apple will stop using leather in its products, including iPhone cases and Watch bands, due to its environmental impact. Instead, it will rely on new materials that have been especially developed, such as recycled yarn and a new "FineWoven" material. The new materials will help make the new Apple Watch Series 9 the first carbon neutral product the company has made.
